awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigating Productive Use of High-Leverage Student Mathematical Thinking
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will examine how secondary mathematics teachers respond to and use students' thinking during whole class discussion. An ongoing challenge for teachers is making the best use of students' emerging mathematical ideas during whole class discussion. Teachers need to draw on the ideas students have developed in order to create opportunities for learning about significant mathematical concepts. This study will create tasks specifically designed to generate opportunities for teachers to build on students' thinking and then use classroom observation and analysis of classroom video to develop tools to support teachers in leading whole class discussion. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The project focuses on the teaching practice of building on student thinking, a practice in which teachers engage students in making sense of their peers? mathematical ideas in ways that help the whole class move forward in their mathematical understanding. This study examines how teachers incorporate this practice into mathematics discussions in secondary classrooms by designing tasks that generate opportunities for teachers to build on students' thinking and by studying teachers? orchestration of whole class discussions around student responses to these tasks. The project engages teacher-researchers in exploring the building practice. The teacher-researchers will use the project-designed tasks in their classrooms and then engage in a cycle of analysis of their own teaching with the research team. Data collection and analysis will rely on video analysis of classrooms, teachers? reflections on task enactment, and data collected during research team meetings convened with teacher-researchers to analyze practice.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Building on MOSTs, a collaborative project, explored how teachers can productively take advantage of Mathematical Opportunities in Student Thinking (MOSTs). MOSTs are high-leverage student contributions ("teachable moments") that occur at the intersection of student mathematical thinking, significant mathematics, and pedagogical opportunity. In essence, MOSTs are student mathematical contributions that provide an in-the-moment opportunity to engage students in joint sense-making. The work of the collaborative project was to develop a conceptualization of a productive way teachers can coordinate their work around MOST--a teaching practice we refer to as building. We worked with teacher-researchers as they enacted the practice and refined the four elements of building: (a) Establish the student mathematics of the MOST as the object to be discussed; (b) Grapple Toss that object in a way that positions the class to make sense of it; (c) Conduct a whole-class discussion that supports the students in making sense of the student mathematics of the MOST; and (d) Make Explicit the important mathematical takeaways from the discussion. 

The work of the 2022-2024 equity supplements was to improve the overall quality and usefulness (generalizability) of the work in the collaborative project by ensuring that the work was aligned with the most recent standards and expectations of the discipline with respect to concerns for equity. To do this work, we created a new research team, Empowerment in Equity (E2). Our approach was novel, not seeking to generate an equity-focused research project, but instead investigating whether existing research products could be revised to address equity. Our results indicate that, through intentionally designed work, it is possible to revise existing research theories, frames, and products to be inclusive of concerns for equity in authentic ways. They also provide guidance about what it takes to do this work, including sample strategies and processes and examples of revised framings. Below, we briefly describe three themes of our results.

High-quality revisions are possible but may require new strategies and approaches. In our analysis of the original project depictions, a common theme that emerged was whether and how minoritized students' whole selves would be recognized and valued, especially their cultural, linguistic, and dis/ability assets, and what needed to be done to avoid the default of reproducing issues of inequity by excluding such students. Our results produced new depictions of the project products that incorporated more precise language to support teachers' use of these products in authentic ways that both met the original goals of the project and advanced equity by being explicitly inclusive of students' full identities. To illustrate what these equity-infused depictions look like, see Figure 1, which shows the original "Core Principles," example comments from E2, and the resulting "Equity-Infused Core Principles." This work, however, was not possible until we created a diverse team of researchers. 

People change people: The identities of research team members matter. The original team of investigators was homogenous and, despite their best intentions, generated work that was identified as unusable by scholars seeking to address equity as a requirement for high-quality research. We learned that the work of attending to equity requires community and diversity of perspectives. It also requires examining and re-distributing power dynamics to ensure that diverse researchers are empowered to shape the research, not just provide feedback. Every aspect of research has built-in assumptions. The diverse team of researchers we gathered (E2) provided our study with useful tools to critique the biases and assumptions in the framings and products and revise them in ways that improved the rigor, quality, and usefulness of the findings. 

Addressing equity can lead to improved quality and usefulness of research. All researchers have a responsibility to continuously critique their research techniques and procedures (i.e. methodological and analytical approaches) to ensure authentic and usable results. In mathematics education, the last three decades have produced specific guidance about inequities that arise in mathematics classrooms and the negative impacts they have on teaching and learning. Given this guidance, all researchers have a professional and ethical obligation to explicitly address concerns for equity within their work. The original project leveraged the illusion of "neutrality" in addressing equity by thinking that "focusing on student thinking addresses equity because focusing on thinking removes biases," instead of recognizing that structures in education (and society) are designed to reproduce inequities. Work that focuses on student thinking must attend to the identities of the students and expand students' opportunities for benefiting from diverse mathematical ideas to ensure that the study doesn't reproduce harm. Therefore, high-quality research must explicitly address equity to be useable by teachers and researchers. 

This work serves as a prototype for breaking down barriers between doing mathematics education research and doing equity research, increasing the opportunities for teachers, teacher educators, and researchers to learn to intervene in, rather than potentially reproduce, issues of inequity in their classrooms and research.
